title: About Me
text:
{.img-fluid rounded-3 shadow-sm}


{.img-fluid rounded-3 shadow-sm}


{.img-fluid rounded-3 shadow-sm}




I’m a third-year undergraduate at UC Santa Barbara pursuing a B.S. in Hydrologic Science & Policy with a minor in Philosophy.
My academic path blends physical science with critical thinking, driving me to ask why water systems matter to society.




At the core of my work is the question:

How will elephants navigate an increasingly fragmented, drier landscape?

Using Sentinel-2 imagery, CHIRPS rainfall data, and Google Earth Engine, I model ephemeral surface-water dynamics and feed these layers into circuit-theory corridors to predict future elephant movement under SSP climate scenarios.
Key skills & tools:

Remote sensing (GEE, terra, raster)

GIS network analysis

R / Python workflow automation






DEI Coordinator, UCSB Hydrology Club — developing outreach events that bring first-generation and historically excluded students into water-science careers.

Plant-based recipe developer — writing a cookbook that pairs global flavors with local produce.

Ocean enthusiast — if the waves permit, you’ll find me open-water swimming at dawn.




Résumé Projects Vegan Cooking
